introduction.p: A function f is given by the graph in the following figure. Use the graph to answer each of the following questions. Note: to the right of x = 2, the graph of f is exhibiting infinite oscillatory behavior similar to the function \sin(\frac{\pi}{x}) that we encountered in the key example early in Section. Assume that f(2) = -2.5.

statement.p: For each of the values a = -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, determine whether or not \lim_{x \to a} f(x) exists. If the function has a limit L at a given point, state the value of the limit using the notation \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L. If the function does not have a limit at a given point, write a sentence to explain why.

For each of the values of a from part (a) where f has a limit, determine the value of f(a) at each such point. In addition, for each such a value, does f(a) have the same value as \lim_{x \to a} f(x)?

For each of the values a = -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, determine whether or not f'(a) exists. In particular, based on the given graph, ask yourself if it is reasonable to say that f has a tangent line at (a,f(a)) for each of the given a-values. If so, visually estimate the slope of the tangent line to find the value of f'(a).
